body:
Note that all tests pass in PowerShell Core on Windows 10 machine. However, 3 of them fail on the AppVeyor build VM, which is Windows Server 2012R2. These 3 tests are disabled for now.
## Steps to reproduce

```
powershell\test\powershell\Modules\Microsoft.PowerShell.Security> Invoke-Pester .\FileCatalog.Tests.ps1
```
## Expected behavior

All tests pass
## Actual behavior

3 tests fail on the AppVeyor build VM (windows 2012R2)

> NewFileCatalogWithMutipleFoldersAndFiles
> Expected: {AFEB46104F506FC64CAB4B0B2A9C6C50622B487A}
> But was:  {ECEE0E902E1392D02D17B1A0C553925D365048EF}
> 
> NewFileCatalogVersion2WithMutipleFoldersAndFiles
> Expected: {6591FE02528D7FB66F00E09D7F1A025D5D5BAF30A49C5FF1EC562FAE39B38F43}
> But was:  {F699D4CA967D1CC303E6AEE4B213646298D11890DB3241439C4232A5353A76CC}
> 
> NewFileCatalogWithUnicodeCharactersInFileNames
> Expected: {6591FE02528D7FB66F00E09D7F1A025D5D5BAF30A49C5FF1EC562FAE39B38F43}
> But was:  {F699D4CA967D1CC303E6AEE4B213646298D11890DB3241439C4232A5353A76CC}
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
```

title: Deactivate PowerShellGet telemetry on CorePowerShell

body: On *nix system, [Test-RunningAsElevated](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/Modules/Shared/PowerShellGet/PSModule.psm1#L7394) needs to use SUDO_UID env variable to figure out that it is running in SUDO mode

labels.description: specific to PowerShellGet module
labels.name: Area-PowerShellGet

title: Update Test-RunningAsElevated in PowerShellGet to work agnostic to platform

body:
On *nix platforms, use the following paths:

See [XDG_Type](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/862b7f4982bb1ffdbd736dc4991908e5a0a54380/src/System.Management.Automation/CoreCLR/CorePsPlatform.cs#L48) for path details
- Default Install Location for Scripts/Modules - $HOME/.local/share/powershell/modules(scripts)
- Config - $HOME/.config/powershell/PowerShellGet [equivalent to Windows $env:LOCALAPPDATA]

labels.description: specific to PowerShellGet module
labels.name: Area-PowerShellGet

title: Environment settings for PowerShellGet needs to be made platform agnostic

## Steps to reproduce
1. Launch PowerShell.exe and run $env:PSModulePath
   You will see the following:

PS C:\work\Node> $env:psmodulepath  
 c:\program files\powershell\0.5.0.289\Modules;C:\Users\kriscv\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules;C:\GitHub\PackageManagementProviderResource;C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\;C:\WINDOWS\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\;C:\GitHub\PackageManagementProviderResource

## Steps to reproduce
1. Run any command that you could interactively block (e.g. `Get-Command`)
2. Hit `Ctrl+Z`
## Expected behavior

Either:
1. Suspend and background the process OR
2. Do nothing
## Actual behavior

All of PowerShell is suspended and backgrounded at the bash level.

<!--

- Search the existing issues.

- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce
- Create a PSC1 file - 'rsc.psc1'

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
  <PSConsoleFile ConsoleSchemaVersion="1.0">
    <PSVersion>5.1.10032.0</PSVersion>
      <PSSnapIns>
    <PSSnapIn Name="doesnotexist"/>
  </PSSnapIns>
</PSConsoleFile>
```
- Create a runspace configuration using the PSC1 file

``` powershell
$x = $null
$rsc = [System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.RunspaceConfiguration]::Create('c:\temp\rsc.psc1', [ref] $x)
```
## Expected behavior

No stack overflow but an error is expected with exception as PSConsoleLoadException.
## Actual behavior

Stack Overflow when having a PSC1 file with an invalid pssnapin.

body:
Two problems were encountered:

1: mc.exe was not found under program files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Windows.
This was worked around via disabling mc.exe discovery: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/commit/dce4bad9d0c15e721ed8b1af0c524883ca10c3a8

2: mscoree.h was not found
The netfx SDK 4.6 is needed to resolve this header.

Both can be addressed via installing the Windows 10 SDK (choco install windows-sdk-10.0 /y); however, build.psm1 still needs to be updated to correctly detect mc.exe when it is needed.

body:
I started tweak some SMA internals. `Start-PSBuild` is a very slow way to do incremental builds.
The reason for slowness is that **everything** depends on SMA, so you are rebuilding the entire world on the slightest change.

If a developer doesn't alternate public API contracts, they should be able to recompile just one dll.

It could be done by calling `dotnet build --output` directly, but it requires some knowledge about build internals.

```
dotnet build --output ./src/powershell/bin/Linux/netcoreapp1.0/osx.10.11-x64 --configuration Linux --framework netstandard1.6 --runtime osx.10.11-x64 ./src/System.Management.Automation
```

We should document this or better provide a friendly way to scope the build to one dll in `Start-PSBuild`.

If it's relevant only for SMA, perhaps we can add `Start-PSBuild -SMAOnly` switch.

body:
I went through the following sub powershell projects in PowerShell repo to search for missing files, by comparing the map.json files and project.json files with the sources files in windows build.
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Diagnostics
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.AssemblyLoadContext
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.Eventing
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.PSReadLine
- [x] Microsoft.PowerShell.Security
- [x] System.Management.Automation
- [x] Modules

The analysis result is as follows, for both Full PS and PS Core:
1. All .resx files are embeded when building CoreCLR assemblies, even though a .resx file is not needed for the CoreCLR assembly
2. Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management:
   - map.json is missing:
     - TimeZoneResources.resx
     - TimeZoneCommands.cs
   - project.json shouldn't exclude for CoreCLR:
     - Computer.cs (#1146)
3. Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility:
   - map.json is missing
     - ~~All string manipulation source files~~ _(they were intentionally skipped due to #726)_
   - project.json needs to exclude for CoreCLR:
     - FormObject.cs
     - FormObjectCollection.cs
     - WebCmdletElementCollection.cs
     - WebRequestMethod.cs
4. Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost:
   - project.json needs to exclude for CoreCLR _(they are now guarded by `!PORTABLE`, but they should be completely excluded from CoreCLR build)_

body:
This bug is breaking "$item.Target | Get-ChildItem" anywhere outside the parent directory of the symbolic link. 

Steps to reproduce:

> mkdir folder
> touch folder/junk
> touch folder/junk2
> ln -s folder link
> $info = Get-Item /absolute/path/to/link # or just `link`

Expected behavior

> cd PowerShell
> $info.Target | Get-ChildItem
> /absolute/path/to/folder
> 
> $info | Get-ChildItem

Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name

---

------          4/27/16   1:45 PM              0 junk
------          4/27/16   2:24 PM              0 junk2

Actual behavior

> cd PowerShell
> $info.Target | Get-ChildItem

PS /home/alexj> $item = Get-Item link
PS /home/alexj> cd ./PowerShell/
PS /home/alexj/PowerShell> $item.Target | Get-ChildItem
Get-ChildItem : Cannot find path '/home/alexj/PowerShell/folder/' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:16
- $item.Target | Get-ChildItem
-                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  - CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (/home/alexj/PowerShell/folder/:String) [Get-ChildItem], ItemNotFoundExcep
    tion

title: Get-ChildItem of Symbolic Link Does Not Work Outside Parent Directory

body:
`System.Management.Automation.Environment.GetEnvironmentVariable(string)` maps some environment variables when they do not exist:

```
OS => "linux"
COMPUTERNAME => HOSTNAME
USERNAME => USER
HOMEPATH => HOME
USERPROFILE => HOME
TMP => TMPDIR
TEMP => TMPDIR
```

There are a couple issues with this.
1. They aren't true environment variables, so child processes won't see $env:HOMEPATH or $env:OS
2. There is no mapping back to Windows
3. Other possibly useful Windows env vars aren't there, like ProgramFiles, AppData, or LocalAppData

If we keep what we have (for portability), I think it's better to define these variables as proper environment variables at startup rather than map them when they are accessed.

Regarding bullet 3, I think these map to XDG directories - do we expose those as an api or env vars?

body:
The module name is too generic, maybe BuildPowerShell.psm1?

And the prefix for commands in the module shouldn't be PS - that prefix belongs to the product, not the tool that builds the product.

Here are some possible names (with almost no real thought here):

Start-PSBootStrap => Start-BootstrapBuildPowerShell
Start-PSBuild => Start-BuildPowerShell
Start-PSPackage => Start-PackagePowerShell
Start-PSPester => Start-TestPowerShell -Pester
Start-PSxUnit => Start-TestPowerShell -xUnit

Assuming the above sounds good, some aliases are desirable too:

Start-BootstrapBuildPowerShell => sbbps

body:
This PR is a request for comment of my work-in-progress to support literal backslashes in filenames (as is allowed on some filesystems, like Linux). Right now, this PR is really no good, but shows what's going on.

This highlights the main problem: PowerShell has no single say in path normalization; instead there are several different "normalization" functions that are all variations on the same theme, and another dozen calls to `path.Replace` to normalize, skipping the functions entirely. This is not unsurprising, given the age and size of the code-base.

However, it presents us with a problem, since supporting literal backslashes in a file-path mandates that the path is both normalized and processed for escape characters once (and only once). We should maybe process globs at the same time, to share code, but on the hand hand, since glob expanding is conditional, perhaps we need to process escape characters only for backslash at first, and later assume the path has been normalized.

No matter what: we need to normalize each path once and only once, accounting for backtick-escaped backslashes.

It would probably be helpful to be passing around path objects (this is PowerShell, isn't it?) instead of strings, but given the public APIs, this would be a bit more work.

/cc @JamesWTruher @lzybkr
title: WIP/RFC path normalization

body:
This is work-in-progress to resolve #839.

This mimics the deprecated `InitializeDefaultLoadContext` by loading our top-level DLL (in this case, `ConsoleHost`) from the loader shim (`src/powershell`) manually with the ALC, then invoking its entry-point via reflection. In this way, all subsequent libraries are loaded through the same ALC (ours).

This also reverts the `ClrFacade.Load` work-around I'd introduced, as this _should_ mean all assemblies are intercepted correctly.

This PR contains debugging and unfinished code, and exists solely to share with @daxian-dbw.
title: WIP AssemblyLoadContext

body:
In Full, the following files are expected in $PSHOME

TypesToProcess="GetEvent.types.ps1xml"
FormatsToProcess="Event.format.ps1xml","Diagnostics.format.ps1xml" 

In Core, ~~they are apparently expected in the module directory (like any other module).~~ they are also expected in $PSHOME, and Nano PS depends on the internal C# `GetEvent_Types_Ps1Xml.generated.cs` and `Event_Format_ps1xml.cs` to handle them.

Normally this isn't a big deal, but the engine currently knows about these files if they are in $PSHOME and uses some internal C#.  That code should probably be removed and we stick with the Core way of doing things, but that requires manifest changes on Full and Core.
